docs.lead_paragraph: The 1 percent drop in drug spending was partly a sign of the rising use of generics, but experts warn that the high cost of specialty medicines could reverse the downturn.

headline.seo: Use of Generics Produces an Unusual Drop in Drug Spending
headline.main: U.S. Drug Costs Dropped in 2012, but Rises Loom
headline.print_headline: U.S. Drug Costs Dropped in 2012, But Rises Loom

docs.abstract: One percent drop in prescription drug spending in 2012 was partly a sign of the rising use of generics, but experts warn that the high cost of specialty medicines could reverse the downturn; potential for higher spending on drugs comes as nation is struggling over how to contain health care costs, which many experts agree is major threat to country's fiscal condition.
docs.snippet: The 1 percent drop in drug spending was partly a sign of the rising use of generics, but experts warn that the high cost of specialty medicines could reverse the downturn.

headline.seo: Women and the Treatment of Pain

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by author Laurie Edwards highlights gender gap in diagnosis and treatment of painful disorders; cites her own experience, in which chronic pain and disease were often explained away as emotional.
docs.snippet: There is a gender gap in the diagnosis and treatment of painful disorders.

docs.lead_paragraph: Health officials say the patient, whose identity was not revealed, and three others received organ transplants from the same donor.

headline.seo: Rabies Killed Maryland Kidney Transplant Patient
headline.main: Maryland Transplant Patient Dies of Rabies
headline.print_headline: Maryland Transplant Patient Dies of Rabies

docs.abstract: Patient in Maryland dies of rabies contracted from kidney transplant, and three other people who received organs from same donor are being treated to prevent the disease.
docs.snippet: Health officials say the patient, whose identity was not revealed, and three others received organ transplants from the same donor.

keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: STABILE--Antoinette D. Columbia University Medical Center (CUMC) is saddened by the death of Toni Stabile, a thoughtful, caring philanthropist who so generously supported the founding and growth of the Toni Stabile Osteoporosis Center under the leadership of Ethel S. Siris, MD. Ms. Stabile first established the Madeline C. Stabile Professorship in Medicine to support Dr. Siris's continuing clinical and research activities and both shared a vision to create a center to increase awareness and encourage early diagnosis and treatment of women and men from all socio-economic backgrounds. Officially opened in 2001, the Toni Stabile Center set a new standard for treatment and management of osteoporosis with its unique combination of patient care, research, education, and state-of-the-art diagnostic equipment. The Stabile Center is also part of the highly regarded Metabolic Bone Diseases Program in the Division of Endocrinology in the Department of Medicine at CUMC. Lee Goldman, MD Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine Executive vice President for Health and Biomedical Sciences
